weaknesses.weakness: Difficulty using logical connectors (conjunctive adverbs) to express relationships between clauses.
weaknesses.description: The student consistently misinterprets the logical relationship between two independent clauses or sentences, leading to the selection of an incorrect transitional word or conjunctive adverb. Errors include confusing contrast with consequence or condition with contrast.

weaknesses.weakness: Incorrect formation and use of the passive voice, especially with modal verbs.
weaknesses.description: The student struggles to construct grammatically correct passive voice sentences. They tend to use active voice forms or incorrect auxiliary verbs when the sentence requires a passive construction, indicating a lack of understanding of when and how to form the passive voice.

weaknesses.weakness: Confusion and misuse of relative pronouns.
weaknesses.description: The student demonstrates difficulty in selecting the appropriate relative pronoun to introduce a relative clause. This includes confusing subject, object, or possessive forms, leading to grammatically incorrect or imprecise sentence structures.

weaknesses.weakness: Incorrect selection of word form (part of speech or number) in context.
weaknesses.description: The student struggles to choose the correct morphological form of a word that fits the grammatical and semantic context of the sentence. This includes confusing singular/plural forms of nouns or misapplying a noun form where an adjective or adverb might be needed, often in idiomatic or fixed phrases.

api_output.user_facing_response:
**TOEIC Part5 Sample Test**

**Current Performance:** You successfully passed the test, scoring 15 out of 20 questions correctly. While this is a good foundation, focusing on the five questions you answered incorrectly presents a valuable opportunity for targeted improvement. Refining your understanding of grammar rules, particularly around sentence connectors and verb forms, will help you achieve an even higher score.

**Area to be Improved:** To elevate your English proficiency, concentrate on enhancing your grasp of logical connectors to clearly express relationships between ideas. Special attention should also be given to the accurate formation and usage of the passive voice, including with modal verbs. Clarifying the proper application of relative pronouns and mastering correct word form selection in context will be key areas for growth.

**Recommended Course:**

- **Conjunctions & Sentence Structure**: This course will clarify how to effectively use coordinating, subordinating, and correlative conjunctions to build complex and grammatically correct sentences, improving overall sentence flow. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-conjunctions

- **Connectors & Transition Signals**: Learn to master the use of conjunctive adverbs and other transitional phrases to create clear, logical connections between ideas and clauses, enhancing cohesion in your writing and speaking. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-connectors

- **Noun Clauses & Relative Pronouns**: This course focuses on identifying and correctly using noun clauses and relative pronouns to introduce dependent clauses, helping you avoid common errors in complex sentence constructions. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-relative-clauses

- **Modifiers & Sentence Logic**: Develop a stronger grasp of how modifiers function within sentences, ensuring they logically connect to the elements they describe and avoiding misplaced or dangling modifiers. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-modifiers

- **Verbs & Tenses for TOEIC Part 5**: Specifically designed for the TOEIC Part 5, this course will review various verb tenses, irregular verbs, and the proper application of active and passive voice, including with modal verbs, to improve your grammar accuracy. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-verbs-tenses

weaknesses.weakness: Misunderstanding of logical relationships conveyed by discourse markers and transition words.
weaknesses.description: The student struggles to identify the correct transition words or conjunctive adverbs that establish appropriate logical connections (e.g., cause/effect, contrast, result) between independent clauses or sentences. This leads to selecting words that imply an unintended relationship.

weaknesses.weakness: Incorrect formation or usage of passive voice constructions.
weaknesses.description: The student has difficulty constructing grammatically correct passive voice sentences, particularly regarding the auxiliary verbs and past participle forms required. This indicates a gap in understanding the rules for shifting sentence focus from the actor to the receiver of the action.

weaknesses.weakness: Confusion between relative pronouns, especially 'who' and 'whose'.
weaknesses.description: The student misuses relative pronouns, specifically confusing subject pronouns like 'who' with possessive pronouns like 'whose' when introducing relative clauses. This suggests a lack of clarity on the distinct grammatical functions of these pronouns within a sentence.

weaknesses.weakness: Incorrect noun form or number choice in context.
weaknesses.description: The student selects an inappropriate form or number of a noun, such as using a plural noun when a singular noun is required to convey a general concept or an uncountable quality. This indicates a subtle misunderstanding of noun usage in specific contexts.

api_output.user_facing_response:
**TOEIC Part5 Sample Test**

**Current Performance:** You achieved a score of 15 out of 20 on the TOEIC Part5 Sample Test, successfully passing this attempt. While this is a good start, there were 5 questions answered incorrectly. To enhance your performance, consider reviewing grammar fundamentals, particularly focusing on sentence structure and word usage in context.

**Area to be Improved:** Your primary areas for growth include a deeper understanding of how discourse markers and transition words establish logical relationships in sentences. Additionally, mastering the correct usage of passive voice, differentiating between relative pronouns like 'who' and 'whose,' and choosing appropriate noun forms will significantly boost your accuracy.

**Recommended Course:**

- **Connectors & Transition Signals**: This course will help you master the use of words and phrases that connect ideas, improving your understanding of logical relationships within sentences. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-connectors

- **Conjunctions & Sentence Structure**: Strengthen your ability to form grammatically correct and complex sentences by understanding how conjunctions work and how to structure sentences effectively. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-conjunctions

- **TOEIC Grammar Essentials**: A comprehensive course designed to solidify your fundamental grammar knowledge essential for the TOEIC exam, covering various critical grammatical concepts. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-grammar-essentials

- **Noun Clauses & Relative Pronouns**: This course specifically targets the usage of noun clauses and clarifies the often-confusing world of relative pronouns like 'who,' 'which,' and 'whose.' - Link: https://example.com/toeic-relative-clauses

- **Countable & Uncountable Nouns for TOEIC**: Improve your accuracy by learning the rules and common pitfalls associated with countable and uncountable nouns, a frequent area of challenge in TOEIC. - Link: https://example.com/toeic-nouns
